course.subject: LIFS
course.name: Biochemistry of Diseases
course.description: This course covers the clinical manifestations, physiology, pathophysiology and treatment of common human diseases, with focus on the underlying biochemical basis of the diseases and treatment.
course.prerequisites: LIFS 1901 OR LIFS 1902 OR LIFS 2040 OR LIFS 2210

reviews.author: Leon2002
reviews.title: A course for students who are interested in diseases and like to memorize drug names
reviews.comment_content:

reviews.author: Kabul
reviews.title: Nice course
reviews.comment_content:
Clinical manifestations, physiology, pathophysiology and treatments of common human diseases, with an emphasis of their biochemical foundations. Very broad coverage but not in depth. Good to know as a life sciences student.

Midterm topics:
1Ô∏è‚É£ Introduction, history of disease and medicine
2Ô∏è‚É£ Neurological diseases
      üî∂ Alzheimer‚Äôs disease
      üî∂ Parkinson‚Äôs disease
3Ô∏è‚É£ Psychiatric diseases
      üî∂ Schizophrenia
      üî∂ Depression
      üî∂ Autism

Final topics:
4Ô∏è‚É£ Cardiovascular diseases
      üî∂ Hypertension
      üî∂ Atherosclerosis
      üî∂ Myocardial Infarction
5Ô∏è‚É£ Endocrine disorders

      üî∂ Diabetes Mellitus (DM)

7Ô∏è‚É£ Infectious diseases
      üî∂ AIDS
      üî∂ Flu/Cold
8Ô∏è‚É£ Cancer

The arrangement of topics is very nice - each topic starts with its biochemical foundations, e.g. we're first introduced the structure of the brain and different kinds of neurotransmitters before discussing the neurological diseases. Some information is slightly outdated, but it isn't a huge problem. Loads and loads of content will start to flood in during the middle of the semester. Make sure you do regular revision since there is a lot of memorize.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof Xia delivered fairly well in his lectures. Overall clear explanation, comfortable pace but sometimes spoke with an accent. The content was at times quite dull and mechanical, but he made it up by having some level of interaction in his classes.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading comprises of the midterm and the final, but I'm not quite sure how the weighting is distributed between the two.

I got 87/100 (mean = 77.2/100) in the midterm and unknown score in the final.

üíØ Final grade: A

The final exam this year became an online open-book Canvas quiz consisting of 2 simple short-answer questions, due to the political situation and the Wuhan pneumonia outbreak. This made it much easier compared to previous years.
reviews.comment_workload: No assignments and projects. The final exam used to require a lot of rote memorization, but with the format of the final exam changed we've had much less workload this year. Yay!

reviews.author: sora200
reviews.comment_content:
You will learn about approximately 8 diseases during the whole course, which is separated into 3:5 as midterm : finals, so prepare for the finals early!

The topics were:
Introduction and a brief history of disease and medicine
Neurological diseases (Alzheimer‚Äôs and Parkinson‚Äôs Diseases)
Psychiatric diseases (schizophrenia, depression and Autism)
Cardiovascular diseases (hypertension and coronary heart disease)
Endocrine disorders (diabetes)
Gastrointestinal diseases (peptic ulcers)
Infectious diseases (AIDS and Flu/Cold)
Cancer


The last 5 chapters are very content-heavy and needs quite some memorization (drug names, receptor names and chemical pathways functions, etc.)
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor does not upload the powerpoint until he is finished with the topic, so people who take the printed powerpoint slides might get a little frustrated at first. But his teaching explanations during lecture is very easy to understand, and he answers any questions the students have during class.

The class is quite interactive as he asks questions from time to time, and if you have a few students who answer the questions the lectures will pass by very smoothly and you might even pick up some interesting facts.
reviews.comment_grading:
Average grading that you would expect in a 4000-range courses. The midterm was easier than expected but the final was harder than expected, so balance them wisely.

Both midterm and finals have MCQ and short answers, but finals contain a few long-answer questions which were 4-6 marks each.
reviews.comment_workload: There are no homework assignments or projects, just 1 midterm & 1 final. However, the amount you need to study for the finals is twice the amount for the midterm so if you wait until the end to study for the finals it might be too difficult to catch up.

reviews.author: Little_Duck
reviews.title: Not Bad
reviews.comment_content:
3 chapters for mid term.
5 chapters for final exam.

Topics including:
Introduction (some history)
Brain and Neurological Diseases
Psychiatric Diseases
Heart Diseases
Diabetes
Peptic Ulcer
Infectious Disease
Cancer

Professor will only upload the pdf after he finished one topic.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor is quite humorous, I didn't feel bored in his lessons.
The lessons were interactive, the professor always ask questions and opinions on certain topics.
In the beginning of each lecture, he spent around 15 mins on reviewing the contents he had covered last time. I love this arrangement personally.
Lecture video is provided.
reviews.comment_grading:
Mid term above mean around 2 SD
Final exam score did not released, got B+ in the end.

The grading is fair, because I didn't put too much time in revising the final exam. Mid-term was simple, some people got full marks in mid-term. Final exam was slightly difficult.
reviews.comment_workload:
Don't need to read any articles. Just need to revise regularly.

For the final exam, strongly recommend prepare for it as early as possible since there are quite a lot of contents.

reviews.author: randomhuman
reviews.title: Decent grade for those with good memorisation
reviews.comment_content:
Interesting, useful and nicely-structured content. Prof sometimes include Chinese medicine concepts in his lectures but only information involving western medicine is examined.

A brief history of human diseases and western medicine
Diabetes mellitus
Free radicals and human diseases
Dyslipoproteinemia and Atherosclerosis
Ischemic heart disease -- angina and myocardial infarction
- Mid Term -
Congestive heart failure
Hypertension
Peptic ulcer disease
Infectious diseases -- antimicrobial agents
Cancer -- chemotherapy
reviews.comment_teaching: If you have taken any courses from RK you probably know what you're getting. His pace is actually moderately slow this semester, which makes it a lot easier to catch up. Also, since he repeats the important concepts over and over, I think if you don't skip any lectures (or at least watch all lecture videos) it shouldn't be that hard to fully grasp all the concepts.
reviews.comment_grading:
As mentioned in the title, decent grading
Mid term: 38%
Final: 42%
Take home essay: 20%

My overall score (weighted): ~74/100, B+
reviews.comment_workload:
Not so heavy. A closed book mid term and a closed book final. I think mid term is a bit easier because there isn't as much to memorise, whereas there are significantly more drugs (and their names) to remember for the final, so it's a bit more tough.

Word limit for the essay is 1000, you need to choose and write about a disease, its biochemical basis and existing treatment.

reviews.author: imlittleqq

reviews.author: biochemisttt
reviews.comment_content:
Midterm
Introduction and a brief history of disease and medicine
Neurological diseases (Alzheimer‚Äôs and Parkinson‚Äôs Diseases)
Psychiatric diseases (schizophrenia, depression and Autism)

Final
Cardiovascular diseases (hypertension and coronary heart disease)
Endocrine disorders (diabetes)
Gastrointestinal diseases (peptic ulcers)
Infectious diseases (AIDS and Flu/Cold)

Most of the slides for explaining mechanisms are straightly copied from cell bio or bich II. If u did well in these 2 courses would be a bonus of studying this course! The content is not difficult to understand but there  is a lot of content for u to memorize.
reviews.comment_teaching: I like this professor very much! He sometimes gives some joke that is related to the content that he is talking about. He really stimulates your interest of studying this course. He also uploads lecture videos and u can always review them if u miss the class. He is also very responsive to students' questions and would explain the content that u asked in detail.
reviews.comment_grading:
The mean is quite high because the questions in exams are quite straight-forward.

Midterm: 68/84
Final was not released.
I got 75/84 in midterm n I think mean in final and eventually got a B for my grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
Only midterm and final, an average life science course.
However, the content is very huge and each explaining slide have more than 300 words and each ppt has more than 100 slides. Do study regularly and study on the slides that he emphasizes in class.

reviews.author: JYC
reviews.comment_content: The course covers a variety of diseases including psychiatric/neurological diseases(Depression, Schizophrenia, Alzheimer's), infectious disease, heart disease, diabetes, peptic ulcer and cancer. It aims at acquainting students with basic knowledge of each disease so the content are not in-depth. Each topic includes history and background, clinical manifestation, pathogenesis and remedy.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor will tell jokes to lift up students' mood. Each lecture begins with a brief revision of the content discussed in the previous lecture. Lecture video is provided. Professor is keen to ask questions to provoke students' thinking. Professor's English is relatively clear.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is fair. Midterm's mean is around 76 out of 100. Final exam's grade is not released. Got a B+ after two or three days of studying. Exam format includes MC + fill in the blank + short question.
reviews.comment_workload: Only one midterm and one final exam. Need to memorise categories of drug for different diseases and their simple mechanisms. Some background information and statistics about diseases covered will be asked in exam too. So most workload comes from memorising these facts.

reviews.author: Jarvis_
reviews.comment_content: The content covers a wide range of diseases. Each disease is not taught very deeply, just briefly introduce is clinical manifestation and treatment. However, sum up there will be a lot to memorize. I am overwhelmed when studying the final exam. You will find the course interesting if your enjoy studying stuff related to disease or human body.
reviews.comment_teaching: XIA Jun is a very good professor. His teaching is fun. He likes to tell stories of how the disease or how the treatment was discovered, which made the lesson less boring. He can also provoke the students to think more about the experiment part on how to study a disease or how the disease is discovered instead of just memorize all the existing know ledges.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading should be fair enough. Mid-term above 0.5 SD and final unknown. I started to studied the final exam two days before. Eventually i got a B+. Btw the mean is quite high in lifs courses , around 80%.
reviews.comment_workload: Just one mid term and onr final exam. The format is the same. Both of them consist MC, fill in the blanks and some short questions. However, the coverage is quite a lot. It will be better to spend some time every week to study.

reviews.author: YSA
reviews.comment_content:
Topics:

MIDTERM:
Introduction and a brief history of disease and medicine
Neurological diseases (Alzheimer‚Äôs and Parkinson‚Äôs Diseases)                                        
Psychiatric diseases (schizophrenia, depression and Autism)

FINAL:
Cardiovascular diseases (hypertension and coronary heart disease)
Endocrine disorders (diabetes)
Gastrointestinal diseases (peptic ulcers)
Infectious diseases (AIDS and Flu/Cold)
Cancer

Topics are extremely interesting. Provides a decent, comprehensive overview of all the common diseases.

The structuring of the topics is quite messed up. There are basically just 2 topics for the midterm, which are relatively easy ones as well. But the final has 5 topics, all very long and complex. If 1 or 2 topics are moved from the final to midterm it would be more balanced. Otherwise the final is too difficult to prepare for.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Excellent professor. Explains every topic in detail and very clearly. Interactive, always asking questions in class, and sometimes funny. Helpful and responsive to any questions.

The lecture notes uploaded online are extremely detailed with 100+ slides for each topic.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm and final (distribution not mentioned, should be around 40% and 60%)

Exams have MCQ, short questions, long questions.

I got 84 in midterm (slightly above mean), final exam marks not released (I expect below mean). Grade B-
reviews.comment_workload: No homework/assignments. Exams require LOT of memorization of disease pathology, symptoms, treatments, etc. Especially for the final exam, too much content, including things like medicine names. Total 500+ slides for final...

reviews.author: bbcb15
reviews.title: Not so good, not so bad
reviews.comment_content:
‚Ä¢ Neurological diseases (Alzheimer‚Äôs diseases, Parkinson‚Äôs Diseases)
‚Ä¢ Psychiatric diseases (schizophrenia, depression and Autism)
‚Ä¢ Cardiovascular diseases (hypertension and coronal heart disease)
‚Ä¢ Endocrine disorders (diabetes)
‚Ä¢ Gastrointestinal diseases (peptic ulcers)
‚Ä¢ Infectious diseases (AIDS and Flu/Cold)
‚Ä¢ Cancer

He is trying to teach a lot to us by giving a lot of details of biochemical substances, which is acceptable for me, but maybe too harsh for some who do not like memorising.
He gives extra cases for us too in lecture notes. (Ebola, which is not in syllabus and he does not test it in any exam)

This course is quite funny if you like medical stuffs, which is not so many in hkust.
Personal suggestion: take this to learn a little bit cancer and decide if you will take personalized medicine or cancer biology. I think this course gives a quick brief of them.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The accent of the instructor is so terrible that i can hardly follow what he is talking to us.
Maybe he knows that so he type everything in the lecture notes, so you can just skip all the classes and memorise it all.

The instructor is really experienced. He is a really certificated medical officer, so u can ask him when you want diagnosis. And that is why he sometimes get too much out of the lecture, giving too much infomation
reviews.comment_grading:
The exam format is Multiple choices, true and false, matching and some short questions.
It is easy to have mean, but you really cannot beat the guys with good brain memorizing all the materials.
Finally got a C range even around mean in both mid term and final exam
reviews.comment_workload: Just midterm and final, so all is well.

reviews.author: BH
reviews.title: Good grade course
reviews.comment_content:
Before mid term : History, neurological disease
After mid term : Heart disease, Diabetes, Peptic ulcers, Cancer and infectious disease

Actually it may not that related to the course title, because apart from the neurological diseases, biochemistry pathway is not that emphasized in the other topics. It contains a lot of medicines and yes you have to remember the principles and the name of the medicines. For me it's not that difficult to understand and memorize. After mid-term there will be more details in pathway and medicines of the diseases but still can handle. Sometimes he gave a lot of details but mainly will not be tested.
reviews.comment_teaching: Xia Jun is a nice and good professor, he talked appropriate amount of the content and the ratio of the time he spent on specific part to the exam ratio is almost 1:1, so you should give attention to the content that he talked for longer time, except for the story of the winner of nobel prizes. He spent a lot of time to talk about the scientific investigation and principles of the discovery, it is interesting to listen and know but it would not be tested in the exam.
reviews.comment_grading: Good grade. Above 1 sd in mid-term and i think i have done well in final (I "think" because he didn't give back our score of final exam) and finally got A-.
reviews.comment_workload: Only mid term and final exam only. The exam is quite straight forward so the main workload is memorizing the content. Final exam have more things to remember but still okay. He tested a lot of medicine and treatments in final exam so the main workload of final exam would be those stuffs.
